## Myth 1: Emotions = Irrationality

:::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
- Emotions make people fall for misinformation

### Solutions?
- Make them less emotional
- Focus on accuracy

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
### The Science:

- Emotions can indicate recognition
- Emotions are functional
:::
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
![](images/curvi-linear_anger.svg)
![](images/WordShiftGraph.png)
:::
:::
::::

## Myth 2: People are gullible

:::: columns
::: {.column width="70%"}
- People are easy to manipulate.


### Solutions?

- Facts! Education!
- Make them more skeptical

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
### The Science: 
- It's hard to change people's mind.
- People are too skeptical.
- [Alarmist narrative](https://doi.org/10.1007/s11109-024-09911-3) has negative effects. 
:::

## Myth 3: There's a lot of misinformation

:::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
### Solutions?

- Reduce it & warn people

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
### The Science:

- Only 1-6% of all news.
- Most people don't read the news.
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
- Motivated minority shares majority of misinfo: [1%](https://www.doi.org/10.1017/S0003055421000290), [5%](https://www.sciencemag.org/lookup/doi/10.1126/science.aau2706), [2%](https://doi.org/10.1080/10584609.2024.2325426)
- Misinformation from the [top](https://reutersinstitute.politics.ox.ac.uk/types-sources-and-claims-covid-19-misinformation)!
:::

## Myth 4: Misinformation drives behavior

:::: columns
::: {.column width="81%"}
- Strong effects on opinions and behavior.

### Solutions?

- Reduce it, facts, warning, inoculations etc.

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
### The Science:

- Russian disinformation attacks during 2016 Trump election: no effects on attitudes, polarization & voting (study [1](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-022-35576-9), [2](https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.1906420116))
- Even mass media have [small effects at best](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/sciadv.abc4046)

:::

## Myth 5: It's social media's fault!

:::: columns
::: {.column width="60%"}
- Algorithms radicalize people
- Echo chambers cause polarization

### Solutions?
:::
::: {.column width="40%"}
![](https://cdn.pixabay.com/photo/2014/04/03/10/53/spiral-311612_1280.png){width="150"}
![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/YouTube_Logo_2017.svg/1920px-YouTube_Logo_2017.svg.png){width="200"}
<!-- ![](images/Guess2023_algorithm_effects.svg) -->
:::
::::

- [Dissolve](https://www.pnas.org/content/115/37/9216) echo chambers & [turn off](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364) algorithms

::: fragment

### The Science:

![](images/google_election_fraud.png){.absolute bottom=230 right=0 width="750"}

- People [look for](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06078-5) radical [content](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2101967118).
- No algorithm effects on opinions & emotions (studies [1](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w), [2](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364), [3](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.add8424))
- Echo chambers are [larger offline](https://doi.org/10.1093/qje/qjr044), reducing them [backfires](https://www.pnas.org/content/115/37/9216).
:::

::: footer
Robertson et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06078-5); Hosseinmardi et al., [2024](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2313377121); 
Munger & Philipps, [2022](https://doi.org/10.1177/1940161220964767); <br>
Nyhan et al., [2023](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06297-w); 
Guess et al., [2023](https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.abp9364);
Guess et al., [2023](https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.add8424);
Bail et al. [2018](https://www.pnas.org/content/115/37/9216);
Gentzkow & Shapiro, [2011](https://doi.org/10.1093/qje/qjr044)
:::

::: notes
- I know this sounds like I don't think there's any problem, which is not true either. 
- I just want to make the point that misinformation (manipulation) is overestimated, it's never a good idea to assume people are stupid, and that not everything is social media's fault. 
- I'll leave you hanging in suspense about what I think the actual role of social media is, you'll have to check out our website, a podcast I did recently, or watch Doc dok 1 on ORF next Friday. 
:::

::: notes

### Misinformation myths

-   People are gullible
-   Emotions make people irrational
-   People are exposed to a lot of misinformation
-   Misinformation has strong effects on behavior
-   Algorithms radicalize people
-   Echo chambers cause the problem

### Truth

- It's hard to change people's minds
- Emotions are functional
- Misinformation (and news) exposure are low
- Persuasion has very small effects
- Algorithms are not an all round solution
- Dissolving echo chambers causes polarization

### Wrong solutions

- reduce misinformation 
- reduce emotions
- make people more skeptical
- reduce echo chambers

### So what is the problem?

-   Reducing misinformation will not make the real problems go away (vaccine hesitancy, ethnic tensions, sexism, racism, polarization)
-   Misinformation as the scapegoat
-   Alarmist narratives reduce trust in reliable news

### Doing the hard work:

-   Improve democratic & medical institutions
-   Improve the media
-   Address misinformation from the top

:::
